p: We quantified seed transmission as a percentage ( ST) and as the total number ( IS) of TuMV- and CMV-infected seeds in 18 Arabidopsis accessions ( Fig. 1 and Table 1). In TuMV-infected plants, the virus was detected in 12/18 accessions, whereas seeds harboring CMV were detected in all accessions. On average, the percentage of infected seeds was higher in TuMV-infected (4.17% ± 1.53%) than in CMV-infected (2.60% ± 0.23%) plants (Wald χ 2 1,775 = 8.59 [where subscript 1 is the degree of freedom of chi squared and 775 the degrees of freedom of the error term in the same chi-squared analysis]; P = 0.003). Similar results were obtained when seed transmission was quantified as the number of infected seeds (2.13 ± 0.19 versus 1.35 ± 0.07 for TuMV and CMV, respectively) (Wald χ 2 1,775 = 13.45; P < 0.001). Both measures of seed transmission depended on the Arabidopsis accession (Wald χ 2 17,759 ≥ 206.42; P < 0.001) and on the interaction between accession and virus species (Wald χ 2 17,759 ≥ 199.62; P < 0.001). Thus, we analyzed both ST and IS for each virus separately.
